Nouse interviews Langwithâ€™s new COLA

20/11/2022

Alanah Hammond speaks to one of the 11 new Cost of Living Ambassadors (COLA) at the University of York

Image by Alanah Hammond

By Alanah Hammond

As part of the University of Yorkâ€™s attempt to help students during the cost of living crisis, they have created 11 new student jobs in which each college will have one Cost of Living Ambassador (COLA).

Managed by central Student Support Services in the Student Hub, the new roles have been created to promote existing help to students, signpost to cost of living information and money saving tips, and feedback information to the University on how they can help students.

Nouse interviewed Langwithâ€™s COLA, Ceri Hughes, who gave us an insight into her role. The job is a six-month contract, subject to five contact hours per week, and is a paid role.

Nouse asked Ceri if she could explain what a COLA does in their role. Ceri explained, â€œWe act as a form of liaison between the University and students, creating a better line of communication on how students are getting affected by the cost of living. We signpost relevant websites, and vocalise the help that is available, pointing students in the right direction."

The cost of living crisis is impacting many students, and so Nouse asked whether Ceri had been personally affected by the crisis. She said, â€œIt has affected everyone, particularly studentsâ€“ the University found that 60 percent of students were concerned about their finances." She added, "For me, food shops and rent prices have more noticeably increased. The University is aware of these troubles, so they have hired us to show what help is available.â€

COLAs offer drop-in sessions for students to talk about their struggles. Nouse asked Langwithâ€™s COLA what other support they offered. Ceri clarified, â€œWe donâ€™t provide support, we are point of contact.Â However, in our drop-in sessions, we pick up on themes that students are struggling with, for example their food shop, and we feed this back to the University."

Ceri added, "We have weekly meetings every Wednesday, and a WhatsApp group chat, and in these we all research and collaborate."Â Nouse asked where these drop-in sessions occurred, and Ceri explained all information is in the weekly newsletter, but that the Campus East college COLAs can be found in the Goodricke Hub every Monday 4-5pm.

In their pioneering roles, Ceri also explained that the COLAs go to free food events, for example the free soup event at Vanbrugh, to talk to students. The Langwith COLA explained, â€œWe get a dialogue going, asking what students are worried about, pointing them in the right direction, telling them about the website Black Bullion, for example".

The Black Bullion is a website designed for students to access financial support information. In this, students have access to expert articles which inform students on matters such as budgeting which helps students make finically informed decisions.

Nouse asked Ceri why she thought it was important for the COLAs to be a student role. Ceri explained, â€œThe University wanted a greater line of communication between themselves and students as they are concerned about studentsâ€™ welfare and want to know what theyâ€™re worried about, so want someone on the ground to do this."

Ceri added, â€œAs students, we can all relate. An external person is not in the same set of circumstances, and, for example, wonâ€™t understand the tricky balance of enjoying social life but also saving money."

She added, "As student COLAs, we have a level of understanding and relatabilityâ€“ we know that money is a very taboo subject, with the University also finding that 11 percent of their students donâ€™t like talking about money. We want to create a friendly environment in which students may feel comfortable enough to speak about their financial worries.â€

Nouse asked whether COLAs like Ceri get an input in what they do in their role. Ceri explained, â€œWe do get a say, and have a very open system of dialogue. For example, with Christmas around the corner, Constantineâ€™s COLA came up with the idea of researching Black Friday deals, which we are now beginning to research.â€

Nouse then asked whether the Langwith COLA believed the University is doing enough to help students with the cost of living crisis. Ceri said, â€œYeah definitely, I think the COLA role in itself is an example of how the University is trying to support students, and the turnaround of the new role has certainly been quick.â€

Ceri recognised that huge cost of living issues such as rent are â€œbeyond the control of the university.â€ Ceri herself has experienced the extortionate prices of rent in York, recognising how expensive it is, but understands there is a limit to how much the University can get involved, since it is up to private landlords.

Yet, Ceri did explain that the COLA role has shown her what support the University is offering. She said, â€œBefore my job, I didnâ€™t know what support was available, but thereâ€™s some great stuff. Itâ€™s our job to signpost this.â€

For example, Ceri explained that the University has food promotions, such as its offer of a hot meal every day below Â£3.95. The University has also offered a â€˜Nisa Price Crunchâ€™ which offers a range of essential products that are sold at a low price.

There is also the Eat at York Loyalty Card which provides stamps and rewards for using the campus coffee shops. Additionally, they also offer food vouchers which are based off of a discretionary basis and for students who are really struggling. YUSU also have many resources on their website to help with the cost of living crisis. For example, they have articles on how to travel on a budget.

Ceri concluded, stating, â€œThe University can only do so muchâ€“ some students wonâ€™t even acknowledge that these deals are available, like me before, but by hiring students for the new COLA roles, we can emphasise these deals for students.â€

In our final question, Nouse asked why Ceri applied to be a COLA. Ceri explained, â€œI applied because I am very conscious of the cost of living crisisâ€“ it is a challenge which all students face and I want to help.â€ Ceri also explained that she is learning invaluable skills such as the importance of communication and creating an open dialogue.

You can find Ceri, the Langwith COLA, in the Goodricke Hub every Monday 4-5pm, and her colleagues are found within the colleges they represent. For example, Alcuinâ€™s COLA is found in the Junior common room, and Vanbrughâ€™s COLA is found in the Vanbrugh dining room.
